Incident.Summary: Traffic Stop / K9 Scan / Possession Of A Controlled Dangerous Substance / Crack Cocaine / Warrant Service

IncidentAddress.IncAddrComment: BLUE STAR MEMORIAL HWY/ PINEY CREEK RD RAMP

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
Unmarked S-12
Property Held Number P-342458
MSP Form 67 (Chain of Custody)
Copy of Warrant


    On 01/05/2023 at approximately 2113 hours, I was sitting stationary westbound Route 50 prior to Piney Creek Road on the right shoulder, when I observed a silver truck towing a camper with no operable lights from the rear. The camper had no running lights or brake lights. The truck and camper took the exit for Piney Creek Road. I got behind the vehicle and activated my emergency equipment, the vehicle stopped at the Exxon Gas station parking lot (2120 Piney Creek Rd, Chester, MD 21619). The vehicle was a silver Chevrolet Silverado bearing Tennessee registration TN124BBHY. The camper with no active lighting was bearing Tennessee registration 03TE716. I approached the driver who had exited his vehicle. I advised him the reason for the stop. The driver told me someone had just flagged him down and told him that just prior to him stopping to get gas. I asked for his license and registration.

    A Maryland driver's license positively identified him as Frederick Sheldon Cade 3rd (W/M DOB: 05/21/1971) of 12507 Atlanta Court, Hagerstown, Maryland 21740.Frederick was unable to provide me with insurance or up-to-date registration on the camper or the vehicle. Frederick advised the vehicle belonged to his mother. He told me that he was coming from Preston, and was heading back to Hagerstown just hauling junk from his mother's property. I advised the PCO of the stop, and requested another unit due to noticing numerous criminal indicators while speaking with the driver. The indicators are as follows: excessive dirt under finger nails, open sores on upper right arm (indicative of drug use), rotten teeth, bad hygiene, hands shaking (excessive nervousness), vehicle in disarray (excessive trash), and a third party vehicle.

    The PCO advised that Frederick was showing an active warrant through Franklin County, Pennsylvania sheriff's office for failure to appear. Maryland Transportation Authority Police Officer Jordan #0701 responded to the scene with his K9 dog Brick #4001 at 2124 hours. I advised Officer Jordan of the circumstances, and requested a scan of the vehicle. He conducted a free air sniff on the exterior of the vehicle, which resulted in the positive alert for the odor of a trained narcotic. Due to the above, a probable cause search was conducted on the vehicle at 2128 hours. Prior to searching the vehicle, I asked Frederick if there was anything in the vehicle he wanted to tell me about, and he said "No." The PCO advised at 2130 hours that the warrant through Pennsylvania was active, and we could serve it. During the search of the vehicle, in the center console, I located a black rubber mat. I lifted the mat up and located a glass smoking device containing a burnt white rock like substance, containing suspected burnt crack cocaine, as well as two glass vials containing a multiple white rock like substance, suspected crack cocaine. I also located two blue plastic caps containing a white powdery substance, suspected crack cocaine.

    At 2137 hours, I advised Frederick of his Miranda Rights, and he waived his rights and wished to speak to me. I told him what I found, and asked what he knew about it. Frederick asked me where it was at, and I told him the center console. I asked him if he had a crack addiction, and he said "Yeah." He told me he had less than 10 dollars worth of stuff. He told me all he had was the crack in his pipe and some residue. He advised that he hadn't been smoking crack recently, and that he had been on Methadone. Frederick told me he thinks it had been sitting in there for a while. At 2139 hours, I placed Frederick under arrest for the active warrant, as well as possession of a controlled dangerous substance. I then transported Frederick back to the barrack for further processing.

    I know due to my training, knowledge, and experience as a Maryland State Trooper, as well as previous drug investigations, that the glass smoking device containing a burnt white rock like substance is crack cocaine, a schedule II controlled dangerous substance. I know that the two glass vials containing a numerous white rock like substance is also crack cocaine, a schedule II controlled dangerous substance. I know that the two blue caps containing a white powdery substance is crack cocaine, a schedule II controlled dangerous substance. At the barrack, the two glass vials containing crack cocaine, the two blue caps containing crack cocaine, and the numerous loose white rock like substance suspected crack cocaine were all weighed the verified at 6.5 grams including all packaging. The clear glass smoking device containing burnt crack cocaine was weighed and verified at trace amounts. All items seized were packaged and processed in accordance with MSP policy and procedures. Frederick was polite and cooperative during the investigation. Frederick was then transported to the Queen Anne's County Commissioner's Office. He was then transported to the Queen Anne's County Detention Center.

I recommend this case closed by arrest.

All events occurred in Queen Anne's County, Maryland.

IncidentProperty.Description: One clear plastic zip lock bag containing two glass vials, two blue rubber caps, and numerous white rock like substance suspected Crack Cocaine. Weight: 6.5 Grams (Including all packaging.)
One plastic zip lock bag containing one clear glass smoking device containing burnt crack cocaine. Weight: Trace Amounts.
